conclusion: To determine if the displacements of cars A and B are the same during the time interval from t = 0 to t = t1, we need to analyze the area under the velocity-time (vt) graph for each car. The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of the car.
Car A's velocity-time graph is a curve that starts at a higher velocity v2 and decreases to a lower velocity v1 at time t1.
Car B's velocity-time graph is a curve that starts at a lower velocity v1 and increases to a higher velocity v2 at time t1.

premise: The area under a velocity-time graph represents displacement.
conclusion: The area under Car A's graph can be approximated as the area of a trapezoid with bases v2 and v1 and height t1.

premise: The area under a velocity-time graph represents displacement.
conclusion: The area under Car B's graph can also be approximated as the area of a trapezoid with bases v1 and v2 and height t1.
Formula for the area of a trapezoid: Area = 1/2 × (Base1 + Base2) × Height

premise: Formula for the area of a trapezoid: Area = 1/2 × (Base1 + Base2) × Height
conclusion: For Car A: Area_A = 1/2 × (v2 + v1) × t1

premise: Formula for the area of a trapezoid: Area = 1/2 × (Base1 + Base2) × Height
conclusion: For Car B: Area_B = 1/2 × (v1 + v2) × t1

premise: Area_A = 1/2 × (v2 + v1) × t1 and Area_B = 1/2 × (v1 + v2) × t1
conclusion: Since the formula for the area of a trapezoid is symmetric with respect to the bases, the areas for Car A and Car B are the same: Area_A = Area_B
